title: 113_hr4985
content: The Act titled "Stop Corporate Expatriation and Invest in America's Infrastructure Act of 2014" includes modifications to rules regarding inverted corporations. The Act "Stop Corporate Expatriation and Invest in America's Infrastructure Act of 2014" amends section 7874 of the Internal Revenue Code to treat inverted corporations as domestic corporations under certain conditions. The Act "Stop Corporate Expatriation and Invest in America's Infrastructure Act of 2014" amends section 7874 of the Internal Revenue Code to address acquisitions of domestic corporations or partnerships where more than 50% of the stock is held by former shareholders after the acquisition. The Act "Stop Corporate Expatriation and Invest in America's Infrastructure Act of 2014" amends section 7874 of the Internal Revenue Code to address acquisitions of domestic corporations or partnerships where former shareholders or partners hold a significant interest in the expanded affiliated group with management and control primarily in the United States. The Act "Stop Corporate Expatriation and Invest in America's Infrastructure Act of 2014" addresses acquisitions of domestic corporations where former shareholders hold a significant interest in the expanded affiliated group with management primarily in the United States. A foreign corporation is not treated as an inverted domestic corporation if the expanded affiliated group has substantial business activities in the foreign country of organization compared to the total business activities of the group. The Secretary may issue regulations increasing the threshold percent in tests for determining substantial business activities. Regulations for management and control of an expanded affiliated group primarily in the United States apply after May 8, 2014. Regulations for the management and control of an expanded affiliated group in the United States focus on the location of executive officers and senior management responsible for strategic decisions, regardless of their titles. An expanded affiliated group in the United States must have significant domestic business activities, including having at least 25% of employees, employee compensation, assets, or income based in the United States. The regulations under paragraph (3) were in effect on May 8, 2014, with references to foreign countries treated as the United States. The Secretary can decrease the threshold percent in tests to determine significant domestic business activities. Conforming amendments were made to section 7874 of the Code. The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years ending after May 8, 2014, including changes to subsections and paragraphs related to domestic and foreign corporations. SEC. 3. TRANSFERS TO HIGHWAY TRUST FUND. Amends the Internal Revenue Code to appropriate $15,566,000,000 to the Highway Account and $3,891,000,000 to the Mass Transit Account in the Highway Trust Fund. Effective upon enactment of the Act.
